statement.tex: Let $f:\N\to\N$ be a function defined as $f(x) = \fx$. Show that $f:\N\to S$, where $S$ is the range of $f$ is invertible. Find the inverse of $f$ and hence find $f^{-1}(43)$ and $f^{-1}(163)$

reason.tex:
%text We haven't found the co-domain $S$ mentioned in the problem. But even then, just by looking at the plot of $f(x)$, we can say that $f(x)$ is % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{lNl}
\hline & \text{Why?} & Also called \\ \hline 1-to-1 & x\neq y \implies f(x)\neq f(y) & Injective \\ \hline Onto & \text{For every }y\in S,\text{ there is a }x\in\N & Surjective \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text And as $f(x)$ is \underline\text{both 1-to-1 and onto}, it is therefore also \underline\text{invertible (bijective)}%
